docs.abstract: NFL Roundup; New York Giants injury report, listing 15 players, provides mixed news for team, including announcement that cornerback Corey Webster will return to play in upcoming game against Philadelphia Eagles; other football news noted.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brian Hoyer won his first two starts for the Browns and will start again on Thursday even though Brandon Weeden is considered recovered from a sprained thumb.
docs.abstract: Profile of Brian Hoyer, who will again be starting quarterback for Cleveland Browns after winning his first two starts, despite recovery of Brandon Weeden from sprained thumb; Hoyer's return to hometown of Cleveland ends difficult period after he was cut by New England Patriots.

docs.abstract: New York Jets coach Rex Ryan briefly considers asking quarterback Geno Smith to wear a color-coded wristband as a teaching aide to ease Smith's decision-making burden when choosing plays; Ryan's decision to reject idea, however, might underscore tight-wire act he has to tread to avoid trampling Smith's confidence.

headline.main: A Yellow Light for the Jets, but No Color-Coded System

docs.snippet: FIFA, a self-regulated body that has been slow to heed calls for reform, has had some meaningful changes to its leadership since awarding the 2022 World Cup to Qatar....
docs.lead_paragraph: FIFA, a self-regulated body that has been slow to heed calls for reform, has had some meaningful changes to its leadership since awarding the 2022 World Cup to Qatar.
docs.abstract: FIFA's controversial decision to award 2022 soccer World Cup to Qatar, and resulting scrutiny, has produced some of the most meaningful changes in decades to secretive and insular organization; number of longtime executives have been replaced by fresh staff with a new willingness to address governance issues.

headline.main: Changes Slowly Coming to FIFA as Problems Put It on the Defensive
